unnormalised: The monsoon clouds hung heavy over Mumbai as I navigated the usual rush hour chaos. It was July 2023, and I, Rohan Verma, a freshly minted cybersecurity analyst at TechSafe Solutions, was already feeling the heat – and not just from the humid weather. My mentor, Mrs. Iyer, had just assigned me my first real project: analyzing a potential data breach at a local e-commerce giant, DesiDeals.com. Their IT head, Mr. Sharma, was frantic; they suspected a significant compromise on 12/07/2023, and customer data, including credit card details, might be at risk. The pressure was immense.
normalised: The monsoon clouds hung heavy over Mumbai as I navigated the usual rush hour chaos. It was July two thousand twenty three, and I, Rohan Verma, a freshly minted cybersecurity analyst at TechSafe Solutions, was already feeling the heat – and not just from the humid weather. My mentor, Mister-s Iyer, had just assigned me my first real project: analyzing a potential data breach at a local e-commerce giant, DesiDeals dot com. Their I-T head, Mister Sharma, was frantic; they suspected a significant compromise on twelfth July two thousand twenty three, and customer data, including credit card details, might be at risk. The pressure was immense.

unnormalised: DesiDeals, a platform selling everything from sarees to smartphones, processed thousands of transactions daily. A breach could be catastrophic, not only financially but also reputationally. Mrs. Iyer, with her 20+ years of experience, calmly outlined the initial steps: log analysis, vulnerability scans, and containment strategies. She emphasized the importance of adhering to ISO 27001 standards, reminding me that compliance was key. She also pointed out the odd timing of the breach, coming right after a major promotional campaign offering 20% discounts.

She emphasized the importance of adhering to I-S-O twenty seven thousand and one standards, reminding me that compliance was key. She also pointed out the odd timing of the breach, coming right after a major promotional campaign offering twenty percent discounts.

unnormalised: I dove headfirst into the logs. The first anomaly I noticed was a series of suspicious login attempts originating from an IP address in China, starting around 02:30 AM IST on the 12th. These attempts targeted administrative accounts, specifically those belonging to the database administrators. A quick vulnerability scan of their web servers revealed a known SQL injection flaw in their product search functionality. This vulnerability, rated as "Critical" in the National Vulnerability Database (NVD), had a Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) score of 9.8. It was a major red flag.
normalised: I dove headfirst into the logs. The first anomaly I noticed was a series of suspicious login attempts originating from an I-P address in China, starting around zero two thirty A-M I-S-T on the twelfth. These attempts targeted administrative accounts, specifically those belonging to the database administrators. A quick vulnerability scan of their web servers revealed a known S-Q-L injection flaw in their product search functionality. This vulnerability, rated as "Critical" in the National Vulnerability Database (N-V-D), had a Common Vulnerability Scoring System (C-V-S-S) score of nine point eight. It was a major red flag.

unnormalised: Further investigation revealed that the attackers had successfully exploited the SQL injection to gain access to the database. They had then dumped the contents of the customer table, which contained sensitive information like names, addresses, phone numbers, and credit card numbers. The size of the data exfiltrated was estimated to be around 500 GB. I immediately alerted Mrs. Iyer, who convened an emergency meeting with Mr. Sharma and his team.

The size of the data exfiltrated was estimated to be around five hundred G-B. I immediately alerted Mister-s Iyer, who convened an emergency meeting with Mister Sharma and his team.

unnormalised: The atmosphere in the conference room was tense. Mr. Sharma was visibly shaken. Mrs. Iyer, ever the professional, calmly presented the findings. She recommended immediate patching of the SQL injection vulnerability, implementing multi-factor authentication for all administrative accounts, and notifying affected customers. She also emphasized the need to involve CERT-In, the Indian Computer Emergency Response Team, as per regulatory requirements. The legal implications of a breach impacting potentially 10 lakh customers were significant.

unnormalised: The next few weeks were a blur of activity. We worked around the clock to contain the damage, patch the vulnerabilities, and restore the system. DesiDeals launched a public awareness campaign to inform customers about the breach and offer credit monitoring services. The incident response team, led by Mrs. Iyer, meticulously documented every step taken, ensuring compliance with GDPR and other relevant data privacy regulations. The overall cost of the breach, including remediation efforts, legal fees, and potential fines, was projected to be over ₹2 crore.

unnormalised: Looking back, the DesiDeals breach was a harsh but invaluable learning experience. It taught me the importance of proactive security measures, robust incident response plans, and continuous monitoring. Cybersecurity wasn't just about technology; it was about protecting people's data, livelihoods, and trust. And in a digital India, that was a responsibility I was ready to shoulder, one line of code and one log entry at a time. From that point, I understood that securing data was as important as building the next app or gadget.
